name: Taking Shape: Recent Acquisitions
description:
Featuring a selection of artworks the Museum added to its permanent collection between 2023 and 2025. 

In response to a series of recommendations from our communities, these pieces actively fill absences in the areas of Indigenous textile practices, contemporary art and fashion from Turtle Island and beyond, and art that speaks to the diverse experiences of people.  

These recent acquisitions represent a commitment to making space for communities who have been absent from or underrepresented in the Museum's collection. With each new addition, our collection will never stop taking shape, continually adapting to reflect the human experience through the textiles.

name: Made By Many: 50 Years of the Textile Museum of Canada
description:
For over five decades, we have developed a collection comprised of living objects, imbued with stories and knowledge of the diverse communities from which they originate. 

This collection has been the foundation of numerous exhibitions, each offering different perspectives on the cultures, histories, and artistic practices represented within it. This exhibition is a celebration of this legacy, one shaped by countless artists, objects, and communities. 

The exhibition unfolds across galleries that trace the Museum's evolution from the present day back to its beginnings in the 1970s.

Made by Many is an opportunity to reflect on the Museum's curatorial direction throughout the past 50 years, showcasing the many approaches, values, and visions that brought these exhibitions to life. Today, the programming, along with the collection, continues to evolve through a renewed commitment to addressing absences and underrepresentation.

name: From Cloth to Code: New Media Responses
description:
Through the perspectives of nine Toronto-based artists, the exhibition reimagines textile heritage and practices using interactive technologies, sound installations, 3-D printed sculptures, animation, neon, and projections. 

Digitally rendered garments reinterpret the narratives embedded in historic fabrics, while 3-D printed forms meditate on material decay and displacement. Interactive components invite viewers to design digital carpets, while immersive soundscapes trace over diasporic histories. Everyday objects such as rugs and combs are recontextualized to expose colonial legacies and their ongoing relevance.  

Each artist approaches the Museum's collection as both catalyst and collaborator, translating these literal threads of memory, identity, and material culture into digital form. The Museum is embracing a new era of textile art, where the fabrics our collection transform into digital responses.

name: BEING THERE: Portraits from the Toronto Art Community, Dimitri Levanoff
description:
You are invited to our new gallery, Koffler301, a space largely dedicated to the work of Toronto artists.

We are excited to open this new space with an exhibition by photographer Dimitri Levanoff, curated by David Liss. 

This exhibition features a selection of 20 portraits of some of the many artists and collaborators with whom Dimitri has worked. This series began in 2015 and was partially inspired by a famous photograph of British painter Francis Bacon in his studio. Dimtri developed his approach through a series of portraits he shot during the pandemic of local small business owners in their shops.

"To celebrate the opening of this new space nothing could be more appropriate than sharing a selection of Dimitri Levanoff's photographs of Toronto artists, the lifeblood of the poetic heartbeat of our city.", says Matthew Jocelyn, General Director of Koffler Arts.

name: Papalote
description:
A Toronto-based Latin music group that has created a unique sound and repertoire rooted in the Cuban tradition of Son Montuno, with its seductive blend of folkloric poetry and complex rhythms.

Musically, Papalote balances rural and urban traditions within the genre. More than interpretive, their adaptive approach and stylistic innovations resonate with listeners and dancers alike. Toes will be tapping!

name: The Comeuppance

location.name: Michael Young Theatre, Young Centre for the Performing Arts

description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the "Multi-Ethnic Reject Group" reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can't escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they've become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?
